instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3024: What is 820-3024? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1370: What is A1370? A1370 is a model number for a 11 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2010, Mid 2011 with EMC 2393, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2796, 820-3024..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message:
Hello everyone i got a macbook air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1370</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that came in with a dim green light and no power. During visual inspection i found that it was missing <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>. I replaced this chip and i still not getting the fan to spin. Could the isl be causing this issue? I checked my voltages and I'm getting the following

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.10v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 16.98v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.25

Thanks,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message: Uhm 3V42 is the first thing you need. The <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> missing could prove very fatal as there is nothing stopping the high side FETs from letting 12V from PPBUS onto 3V and 5V rails. I think this board will be a time waster.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message: will i be able to get pp3v42 without the <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>? im thinking of removing that chip and focusing on the pp3v42 and then take it from there. Thanks!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message: Why would you remove that chip when you know it's going to send 12v down your 3.3 v and 5v rails?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message: No, you cannot remove a controller chip, it can destroy the board. I'm pretty sure this board is already fried to hell.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3024</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B with dim green light
threads.message: I have returned the macbook to the customer. Thanks for your input dukes!
